Introduction

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhea.  Its clinical manifestations are broad, ranging from asymptomatic infection to severe, disseminated infection.  It has high rates of transmission and is a significant global disease, affecting primarily sexually active young adults.

Pathogenesis



N gonorrhoeae is primarily transmitted through sexual contact; howevever, vertical transmission can occur during vaginal delivery.  N gonorrhoeae has multiple virulence factors that allow it to cause local and disseminated disease.  The bacteria invade epithelial cells, causing cell death, inflammation, and the characteristic purulent discharge associated with gonorrhea.  Dissemination can occur through the bloodstream, leading to systemic symptoms in severe cases.  The process of pathogenesis involves the following:



  • Attachment and invasion (
    figure 1
    ):  N gonorrhoeae expresses a number of surface molecules that allow it to attach to host epithelial cells and neutrophils.  Interactions between host and bacterial surface molecules then allow gonococci to invade host cells, where they can then replicate intracellularly and cause local disease at the site of inoculation.

    • Pili, proteinaceous projections on the outer surface of the bacterium, allow it to attach to epithelial cells.  Interactions between pili and host cells lead to internalization of gonococci into the host cell in vacuoles.
    • Gonococcal membrane porin proteins (PorB) allow for transport of molecules across the cell membrane to mediate host cell invasion.
    • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS) attach to receptors on urothelial cells and sperm.  This attachment to sperm may contribute to male-to-female transmission of infection.
  • Dissemination:  Some strains of N gonorrhoeae express a membrane porin protein (PorB1A) that can downregulate the complement system, allowing the bacterium to be relatively resistant to complement-mediated killing.  These strains can disseminate through the bloodstream and cause disease distant from the site of inoculation.
  • Evasion of host immune defense:  Antigenic variation occurs in outer membrane structures, including pili, porin proteins, and LOS, allowing for repeated infection without recognition by the immune system.  The carbohydrate portions of bacterial LOS are molecularly similar to host glycolipids (molecular mimicry), preventing the host immune system from recognizing them as foreign. N gonorrhoeae also produces IgA protease, which destroys host IgA antibodies.  In addition, gonococci cause downregulation of CD4 T-cell proliferation and inhibition of antibody production by B cells.

Risk factors



  • Sexual activity:  There is an increased risk with unprotected sexual contact, a new sexual partner, multiple partners, and for men who have sex with men (MSM).  In addtion, HIV infection or a prior sexually transmitted infection increase the risk for gonococcal infection.
  • Demographics:  Young age (highest incidence at age 20-24), substance use, and lower socioeconomic status are associated with increased risk.
  • Immunocompromise:  Immunocompromised individuals (particularly those with a deficient complement system) are at increased risk for severe and disseminated infection.

Clinical manifestations

Male urogenital infection



  • Urethritis:  Infection of the urethra is frequently asymptomatic but may cause purulent urethral discharge (more common with gonococcal urethritis than urethritis caused by other pathogens) and dysuria.  When symptoms are present, they develop within several days of acquisition of the infection.
  • Epididymitis:  Infection of the epididymis can lead to unilateral scrotal pain and swelling that improves with elevation of the testes (positive Prehn sign).
  • Prostatitis:  Infection of the prostate can cause fever, pelvic and perineal pain, dysuria, and obstructive voiding symptoms (eg, hesitancy, dribbling).

Female urogenital infection



  • Cervicitis (
    figure 2
    ):  Cervical infection is most commonly asymptomatic.  When symptomatic, patients often have purulent or mucopurulent cervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding.
  • Urethritis:  Inflammation of the urethra usually occurs with concomitant cervicitis (but is the primary site of genital infection in patients who have undergone hysterectomy).  It is typically asymptomatic but may cause urinary symptoms (eg, dysuria, urinary frequency).
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  PID is a polymicrobial infection of the upper genital tract (ie, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries) in which N gonorrhoeae is a common contributing pathogen.  About 15% of cases of gonococcal cervicitis progress to PID.  PID causes pelvic or abdominal pain that may be accompanied by fever, abnormal uterine bleeding, and mucopurulent cervical discharge.  More severe cases can lead to tuboovarian abscess, Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome (inflammation of Glisson capsule surrounding the liver), and sepsis.  PID leads to scarring of the fallopian tubes and an increased risk for infertility and ectopic pregnancy.
  • Urogenital infections during pregnancy:  Infection can increase the risk for complications, including intraamniotic infection, preterm prelabor rupture of membranes, preterm delivery, and spontaneous abortion.

Extragenital infection



  • Gonococcal proctitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  Rectal infection can occur through receptive anal intercourse and via proximal spread from the vagina.  Manifestations typically include tenesmus, mucopurulent anal discharge, and pruritus; rectal fullness, bleeding, anorectal pain, and constipation can also occur.
  • Gonococcal pharyngitis (
    figure 3
    ):  Infection can occur with oral sex; patients have sore throat and cervical lymphadenopathy; some may have associated tonsillar exudates.
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis:  This severe infection can threaten vision; it is typically caused by autoinoculation from genital infection and presents with profuse mucopurlent conjunctival discharge, eyelid edema, and injection of the conjunctiva.

Disseminated infection



  • Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome (eg, tenosynovitis, dermatitis, polyarthralgia):  Patients have migratory polyarthralgia that tends to be asymmetric and can affect small and large joints, painless skin lesions (typically pustules), tenosynovitis, and fever.  Symptoms usually begin within several weeks of infection, but most patients do not have symptoms of genital infection.  Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome is the most common presentation of disseminated infection and can progress to purulent arthritis if untreated.
  • Purulent arthritis:  Sudden onset of pain and swelling of one or more distal joints (eg, wrists, knees, ankles) is seen.

Neonatal infection



  • Ophthalmia neonatorum:  This is the most common manifestation of gonococcal disease in newborns and onset occurs several days after birth.  It most commonly causes conjunctivitis, with purulent exudate, injection, and edema of the eyelids, and can occasionally progress to corneal ulceration and blindness.
  • Other local infection:  As in adults, infection of the pharynx, vagina, urethra, and anus can occur in infants and may or may not be symptomatic.  A scalp abscess can develop in infants of mothers who had intrapartum placement of a fetal scalp electrode, which creates a break in the skin to allow bacterial entry.
  • Disseminated infection:  Local infection (particularly scalp abscess) can lead to gonococcal bacteremia and disseminated infection, which typically present as arthritis, meningitis, or sepsis.
    • Arthritis:  The most common form of disseminated infection, arthritis usually affects multiple joints and presents within the first 3 weeks of life.  Infants may have reduced movement or pain with manipulation of the affected joint.
    • Meningitis:  Meningitis presents with temperature instability (eg, fever, hypothermia), irritability, poor feeding, seizures, lethargy, and decreased activity.
    • Sepsis (uncommon):  Neonatal sepsis typically presents with nonspecific symptoms, including respiratory distress, fever, poor feeding, irritability, hypoperfusion, and lethargy.

Diagnosis and laboratory evaluation

Evaluation of local infection



Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is the preferred method for diagnosing gonorrhea due to high sensitivity and specificity rates.  In male patients, NAAT can be performed on a first-catch urine specimen or urethral swab.  In female patients, NAAT performed on a vaginal or endocervical swab is preferred, but it can also be performed on a first-catch urine or liquid Pap test specimen.  NAAT can also be performed on rectal or pharyngeal swab if indicated by sexual activity or symptoms.



NAAT, however, does not allow for testing for antimicrobial sensitivity.  Therefore Gram stain and culture may be used.  Gram stain is typically performed only in evalaution of symptomatic urethritis in male patients and in those with suspected conjunctivitis or septic arthritis.  A Gram stain demonstrating gram-negative intracellular diplococci is diagnostic (

image 1
).  Culture is typically collected with cases requiring a Gram stain and in cases of cases of suspected treatment failure to evaluate for antibiotic resistance (because it allows for antimicrobial susceptibility testing).  Culture is performed with Thayer-Martin media, and swabs can be taken from the penile urethra, cervix, rectum, posterior pharynx, or conjunctival discharge.

Evaluation of disseminated infection



Diagnosis of disseminated gonococcal infection is made by identification of N gonorrhoeae by culture or NAAT performed on a skin lesion (rarely performed), blood, or synovial fluid.  Evaluation of patients with suspected disseminated infection should include the following:



  • Urogenital, rectal, and pharyngeal testing:  NAAT or culture.
  • Blood cultures.
  • Synovial fluid analysis:  This should be performed in patients with an accessible joint effusion.  Fluid is sent for NAAT, culture (low sensitivity), Gram stain, and white blood cell count.

Evaluation of coinfection



Because of the proclivity for other sexually transmitted infections, patients diagnosed with gonorrhea should be tested for other sexually transmitted infections, including chlamydia, HIV, and syphilis.

Management

Adult management



  • Uncomplicated local infection:  Infections are isolated to the lower genital tract, conjunctiva, or pharynx.
    • Treatment is with a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone.  For patients with a significant allergy, a combination of gentamicin and azithromycin can be used instead for urogenital infections; there are no reliable alternatives to ceftriaxone for pharyngeal infections.
    • A test of cure is not recommended for uncomplicated urogenital infection (but should be obtained 1-2 weeks after treatment of pharyngeal infections due to lower cure rates).  An exception to this is pregnancy, in which a test of cure is obtained due to the risk for neonatal infection.  In addition, due to high rates of reinfection, patients should be retested 3 months after treatment.
  • PID:  Because PID is a polymicrobial infection, broad-spectrum antibiotics (typically ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole) are recommended.  Patients may be managed in an outpatient or inpatient setting depending on the degree of illness.
  • Disseminated infection:  Arthritis syndromes are treated with intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone and then an oral antibiotic once there is clinical improvement.  Patients with more serious disseminated disease (eg, meningitis, endocarditis) require higher dose intravenous treatment.


If chlamydia infection has not been excluded by testing, patients treated for gonorrhea should also be treated for chlamydia with a 7-day course of doxycycline because of the high rate of coinfection.  Pregnant patients are treated with azithromycin instead of doxycycline.



In addition, all recent (within 60 days) sexual partners of patients with gonorrhea should be referred for testing and treatment.

Neonate management



  • Ophthalmia neonatorum is treated with regular irrigation of the eyes and a single dose of intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone.
  • Disseminated infection and scalp abscess are treated with a weeklong course of intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone.  Duration is extended to 10-14 days for meningitis.

Special consideration - antibiotic resistance



N gonorrhoeae has developed resistance to multiple classes of antibiotics, including penicillins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and macrolides.  There is also a trend to decreasing susceptibility to cephalosporins and azithromycin.  Antibiotic-resistant strains are particularly prevalent among MSM.

Screening recommendations



  • Females:  Screening for urogenital gonorrhea is recommended for all sexually active women age <25 and those age â‰¥25 with additional risk factors, including:
    • A new partner or multiple partners
    • A partner with a sexually transmitted infection or multiple partners
    • Prior sexually transmitted infection
    • History of incarceration
    • History of exchanging sex for money or drugs
  • Pregnancy:  Screening is recommended for all pregnant women age <25 and those age â‰¥25 with additional risk factors.  Screening should be performed at the initial prenatal visit and again in the third trimester.
  • Males:  Screening at least annually is recommended for MSM (site of testing is dependent on sexual practices and risk for exposure).  There is no consensus regarding screening for male individuals who exclusively have sex with females and have no additional risk factors.
  • Patients with HIV:  Screening is recommended at the time of diagnosis and then at least annually.

Prevention



The most effective means of prevention is with safe sex practices (eg, consistent condom use), routine screening in at-risk populations (to identify asymptomatic cases and reduce transmission), and expedited partner notification and treatment (to prevent reinfection and further transmission).



In addition to these measures, postexposure antibiotic prophylaxis can be considered in certain high-risk populations, including MSM, transgender women, and survivors of sexual assault.



Neonatal disease can be prevented by routine prenatal screening to reduce the risk for vertical transmission.  In addition, routine universal neonatal prophylaxis with erythromycin ointment to the eyes is recommended within 24 hours of birth to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum.

Prognosis



For most uncomplicated urogenital infections and disseminated disease in adolescents and adults, prompt treatment usually results in a good prognosis.



In female patients, gonorrhea infection can lead to PID, which can have permanent consequences such as chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and tubal damage that can predispose to ectopic pregnancy.  Serious complications of PID, such as tuboovarian abscess and sepsis, can be fatal.



Pregnancies complicated by maternal gonorrhea are at increased risk for preterm prelabor rupture of membranes, preterm delivery, and subsequent complications of prematurity (eg, respiratory distress, cerebral palsy).  In addition, approximately 40% of neonates born to mothers with cervicitis will acquire gonorrhea.  Most cases of ophthalmia neonatorum respond to antibiotics, but it can rarely lead to blindness, especially in areas where prophylaxis is not routinely performed.

Summary



Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is a global health concern due to its high prevalence and increasing antibiotic resistance.  Infection is frequently asymptomatic, contributing to high rates of transmission.  Screening, partner notification and treatment, and safe sex practices are critical to reducing morbidity and transmission.  Although most infections respond to antibiotics, serious and life-threatening complications can occur, making prompt diagnosis and treatment essential to optimizing outcomes.
